div.p: RAJASTHANI (properly Rājasthānî, the language of Räjasthãn of Rajputana), an Indo-Aryan vernacular closely related to Gujarati ( q. v. ). It is spoken in Rajputana and the adjoining parts of central India, and has several dialects the principal of which are Jaipurī, Mārwāṛī, Mēwātī and Mālvī. Hāṛauṭī, an important variety of Jaipurī, is spoken in the states of Kota and Bundi. Carey, the well-known Seram-pur missionary, paid great attention to Rajasthani in the early part of the 19th century, translating the New Testament into no fewer than six dialects, viz. Hāṛauṭī, Ujainī ( i. e. Mīlvī), Udaipurī (a form of Mãrwãp), Mãrwãp proper, Jaipurī proper and Bîkänërï (another form of Mãrwãp). In 1901 the total number of speakers of Rājasthānī was 10,917,712. (G. A. Gr. )
